David V. Olivier wrote:

> I use JUnit for about 90% of my code.  I would like to use it for 100% but 
> I consistently find automated testing of certain types of functionality 
> particular difficult to accomplish.  My work is in digital mapping, and I 
> find complex operations on large data sets problematic.
> 
> Let me give a specific example:
> 
> I am currently implementing functionality to warp satellite images from one 
> mapping projection to another.  The image is distorted according to a 
> complex formula.  On a low level, I can test that for a given input my 
> implementation of the formula provides the result I expect, but on a higher 
> level I haven't been able to automate verification of that the final image 
> is correct.  I have only been able to superimpose the result on a 
> background map I know is correct and eyeball the results.

This sounds like an acceptance test problem to me, not a unit test 
problem (read or re-read the various XP books on the subject).  In order 
to generate this complex map, you're iteratively processing data, right? 
  Well, unit test the processing functions to make sure that they're 
generating correct numbers in the simplest cases.  That should already 
be unit-testable (and it sounds like you're already on the right track 
there).  Now, for the large-scale results, write an acceptance test 
feeding a known good dataset in, save the output as a file (the image is 
a file, right?), and bitwise-compare it to a known good output.  I'm 
presuming your model is deterministic and identical inputs always 
produce identical outputs.  An MD5 checksum can check for you at roughly 
the speed of disk access for the file.  Script it!

Basically, it sounds hard to unit test because it isn't a unit test 
problem.  Treat it on the proper level and it should be much easier. 
(Note that this approach doesn't always work... some years ago, i was a 
build engineer for a cross-platform ERP system.  I wrote a neat little 
script to diff the 600+ compiled binaries so i knew what changed from 
one build to the next.  Worked great on Unix.  But on Windows, the 
compiler embedded a timestamp in the binary, so no two binaries were 
ever bitwise-identical.  Sigh.)
